FoD Vulnerabilities Source Configuration

When loading vulnerability data from FoD, the configuration file must include a bean definition that configures FoD-related functionality.

This configuration is defined using the following bean definition in the configuration file:

<bean class="com.fortify.bugtracker.src.fod.config.FoDSourceVulnerabilitiesConfiguration">

This bean definition supports the following properties:

  • filterStringForVulnerabilitiesToBeSubmitted: Set the FoD filter string to get the list of vulnerabilities to be submitted to the external system. Information about the format of this filter string can be found in the FoD API documentation, and you can use the FoD API Explorer to test your filter strings.

  • includeSuppressed: By default, vulnerabilities that have been suppressed will be excluded when submitting vulnerability data to the external system. This behavior can be changed by setting this property to true. Note that you may need to change some other settings as well in order for this setting to become effective. For example, the default isVulnerabilityOpenExpression will consider suppressed vulnerabilities as not open and thus exclude them from being submitted to the external system.

  • includeFixed: By default, vulnerabilities that have been fixed will be excluded when submitting vulnerability data to the external system. This behavior can be changed by setting this property to true. Note that you may need to change some other settings as well in order for this setting to become effective. For example, the default isVulnerabilityOpenExpression will consider fixed vulnerabilities as not open and thus exclude them from being submitted to the external system.

  • addNativeBugLink: In most cases, FortifyBugTrackerUtility will need to keep track of which FoD vulnerabilities have been submitted to which target issues, for example to avoid re-submitting vulnerabilities that have been submitted previously, and to perform state management. If this property is set to true, information about submitted target issues will be stored as native FoD bug links. Alternatively, bug links can be stored in FoD vulnerability comments; see the addBugDataAsComment property below. Note that storing native bug links is the recommended approach for the primary bug tracker integration, as this provides better user experience (users can click the ‘View Bug’ button to navigate to the corresponding target issue), and results in better performance during bug state management.

  • allowedBugTrackerTypes: When adding native bug links, the utility can check whether the FoD application has been configured with one of the bug tracker types listed in this property. The utility will reject submitting any vulnerabilities to a target system if the bug tracker configured on FoD does not match any of the allowed bug tracker types listed in this property. The special value None can be used to match any FoD applications that do not have a bug tracker configured; this is only supported on FoD 20.2 and higher. This property will be ignored if addNativeBugLink is set to false, or if this property is set to an empty list. For backward compatibility, the default value of this property is Other. Most common is to use either ‘Other’ or ‘None, Other’, with the latter allowing the utility to process release for which no bug tracker has been explicitly configured on FoD.

  • addBugDataAsComment: As an alternative to the addNativeBugLink property, information about submitted target issues will be stored as FoD vulnerability comments if this property is set to true. Note that this is only recommended if the native FoD bug link field is to be used for other purposes (for example if vulnerabilities are to be submitted to multiple external systems), or if you have been running the utility with addBugDataAsComment enabled in the past. Changing between the two methods for storing the bug link will result in all vulnerabilities being resubmitted.

  • commentTargetName: By default, FortifyBugTrackerUtility will use the target name to identify relevant vulnerability comments. This property allows you to override the target name, for example if you want to submit vulnerabilities to multiple instances of the same target system, like a Jira system used by development teams, and another Jira system used for risk management. Note that if you change this after vulnerabilities have already been submitted to a target system, FortifyBugTrackerUtility will no longer consider these vulnerabilities as having been submitted previously.

  • commentTemplateExpression: This property can be used to fully customize the format of vulnerability comments for submitted target issues. This is an SpEL template expression that can optionally reference the id property and must reference the deepLink property. Use with care, as FortifyBugTrackerUtility may be unable to identify already submitted vulnerabilities in case of an incorrect expression. Note that if you change this after vulnerabilities have already been submitted to a target system, FortifyBugTrackerUtility will no longer consider these vulnerabilities as having been submitted previously.

  • regExFiltersForVulnerabilitiesToBeSubmitted: Allows for defining a map of regular expressions, with each entry defining a vulnerability property as the key, and a corresponding regular expression to be matched as the value. Only vulnerabilities for which all of the configured properties match the corresponding regular expressions will be submitted to the target system. Note that vulnerabilities need to be loaded from FoD in order to evaluate these regular expressions, so for performance reasons it is recommended to use FoD specific filtering options whenever possible.

  • isVulnerabilityOpenExpression: SpEL expression that defines whether a vulnerability should be considered open or closed. If the vulnerability should be considered as ‘open’, this expression should return true, otherwise this expression should return false. If not defined, the following expression will be used as default: ‘closedStatus==false && isSuppressed==false && status!=4’. If you do override the default expression, you will usually want to include this default expression. Note that when submitting new issues, any issues for which this expression evaluates to ‘false’ will not be submitted to the target system.

  • extraVulnerabilityData: Allows for loading extra vulnerability data from FoD. This property takes a map, with each entry defining a property name as the key, and relative FoD API endpoint URI as value. The URI may contain request parameters like ‘fields’ or ‘embed’. All fields returned by such an endpoint can then be referenced through ${key.fieldName} by the various vulnerability-related expressions defined elsewhere in this configuration file. These endpoints are called on-demand whenever a corresponding property is requested, and will be cached for individual vulnerabilities. If you define any endpoints that are relevant for multiple vulnerabilities (i.e. related to application version/release, artifacts, scans, …), you may want to add ‘;cache=true’ to the endpoint URI to avoid calling the same endpoint for each vulnerability.

Following are examples of the bean configuration:

	<bean class="com.fortify.bugtracker.src.fod.config.FoDSourceVulnerabilitiesConfiguration">	
		<property name="filterStringForVulnerabilitiesToBeSubmitted"><value>
			severityString:Critical|High+isSuppressed=false
		</value></property>
		
		<property name="addBugDataAsComment" value="false"/>
		<property name="addNativeBugLink" value="false"/>
		
		<!-- This property defines the expression for evaluating whether an FoD 
		     vulnerability should be considered open or closed. This expression
		     can use any FoD vulnerability attribute. Commonly used attributes
		     for this expression include closedStatus and isSuppressed. -->
		<property name="isVulnerabilityOpenExpression"><value><![CDATA[
			closedStatus==false && isSuppressed==false && status!='Fix Validated'
		]]></value></property>
	</bean

	<bean class="com.fortify.bugtracker.src.fod.config.FoDSourceVulnerabilitiesConfiguration">	
		<property name="filterStringForVulnerabilitiesToBeSubmitted"><value>
			severityString:Critical|High+isSuppressed=false
		</value></property>
		
		<!-- Note that previous versions of this sample used to store bug data as comments instead of using native bug links -->
		<property name="addBugDataAsComment" value="false"/>
		<property name="addNativeBugLink" value="true"/>
		<property name="allowedBugTrackerTypes" value="None, Other"/>
		
		<property name="isVulnerabilityOpenExpression"><value><![CDATA[
			closedStatus==false && isSuppressed==false && status!='Fix Validated'
		]]></value></property>
	</bean
